Problem:
Consider a Fourier transform \\( \\mathcal{F} \\{ f(x) \\} = \\int_{-\\infty}^{\\infty} f(x) e^{-i \\omega x} \\, dx \\) and its inverse transform applied to a signal \\( f(x) \\). This approach is used to analyze the modifications in the signal spectrum when multiplied by a Gaussian, \\( g(x) = e^{-ax^2} \\), where \\( a \\) is a positive constant.

If \\( g(x) \\) is multiplied to \\( f(x) \\) at time \\( t = 0 \\) and then its Fourier transform is taken, will the resulting spectrum be the same as if \\( f(x) \\) was transformed without multiplication by \\( g(x) \\)?
Explanation: Multiplying \\( f(x) \\) by the Gaussian \\( g(x) \\) alters the signal by damping it before the transform. This damping changes the frequency components leading to a different spectrum. The Gaussian acts as a frequency filter, emphasizing some components while suppressing others.
